Topic.Title: Sold some at $260

Message.Msg: "260 * x% + $0 (100-x%) = $135 + $40... Solve for X..." What's the point of solving for X when the equation in meaningless? Here's one correct way to set up a set of two equations: Eq. 1: C = $135 * y, where C is the total cost of the purchase Bruce made 3 years ago, and y is the total number of shares he bought then. Eq. 2: $260 * x = C + $40 * (y - x), where x is the number of shares Bruce sold at $260. Solve for the ratio of x over y. x/y = 175/ 300 = approximately 0.5833. So Bruce sold about 58.33% of the shares he bout at $135 three years ago. However, this is based on the assumption that he hasn't bought and held any additional shares after the initial purchase at $135 a share three years ago. If my memory serves me correctly, he has bought more shares much below $260 on several occasions at least, and he made profits on all of them as well along the way. I don't know if he sold all of those shares he bought for short to mid-term trading purposes. He may have accumulated more shares in the last three years.

Topic.Title: How many knuckleheaded dopes could possibly be left buying these levelz

Message.Msg: "I'll always be here until reality sets in on this" I think he means he can't get out because he gambled on options and so is basically locked into a loss. Every short says the "until reality sets in" bit, but the trouble is none of them really know from what to what the stock might move "when reality sets in". And "reality" could be a price that is much higher than today. Unfortunately for shorts it almost always is. "It will be interesting to see if people are flocking to the Kindle" Actually, you can already see that they are. All the top slots under Amazon Electronics, Bestsellers, are taken by each of the different Kindle models. There is simply a very large installed base of users who will always buy the new models. After all they have huge switching costs since thousands of content items are on those platforms now. Plus they go out and gift Kindles to others who end up further expanding that already very large base. "or if they are waiting to see what Apple is going to do. I suspect more are doing the latter right now..." It doesn't matter how many people might be doing that. And in fact a lot of people just own both. It often is not an either/or purchase. This is where the shorts get it really, really wrong. It does not help you if you are short if Amazon sells a zillion Kindles and Apple sells more than a zillion. Amazon stock still goes up a lot from where you shorted, you bite dust, longs laugh there heads at you, you go home and cry to your Mommy some kind of silly nonsense about how Bernake faked you out. End of story.

I will note that your second equation is wrong based upon the information that was provided (he said he'd make $40 a share if everything he held goes to zero, which is not what you've modeled. Equation 2 should be $260*x=C+40y because he said he'd make $40 per share on the original purchase even if all remaining shares went to zero). Regardless, it was simply meant to illustrate that our friend Bruce wisely took the majority of his winnings off the table (which even your calculation shows and is the bigger point so that we do not get lost in minutia). Kudos for doing so. I want longs to do well. I don't want them to make the mistake that some made with NFLX or GMCR and see the majority of their "wealth" vaporize quickly because of a misplaced belief that the scam will continue working into perpetuity.

Message.Msg: Although the market has become a rigged casino, I am taking a calculated risk where the distribution of potential returns is skewed massively in my favor. Because my system employs a massive (never less than 50%) cash hedge, I have no problem riding this up as high as they take it. The behavior here isn't white as unnatural as some other stocks (which are clear short capitulation squeezes), but close. Amazon needs massive incremental growth in its user base or it is hosed. The threat of apple on digital books is massive. Look at Apple's stats on iTunes users vis a vis Amazon Prime / Kindle device users. Apple's installed base of readers is growing way more rapidly than Amazon's. Amazon has never faced competition and diminished profitability in its core business and cash flow machine, but it will going forward.
